Dm'd you it
Some high level take-aways from this morning‚Äôs conversation with Guy:
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Some high level take-aways from this morning‚Äôs conversation with Guy:

content.body: Everyone agrees that virtual import hooks are not serializable.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Everyone agrees that virtual import hooks are not serializable.

content.body: I‚Äôm conceding that `new Worker().addModule(virtualModuleInstance)` should throw an error because its `importHook` isn‚Äôt serializable, rather than just silently stripping it off.
content.formatted_body: I‚Äôm conceding that new Worker().addModule(virtualModuleInstance) should throw an error because its importHook isn‚Äôt serializable, rather than just silently stripping it off.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: I‚Äôm conceding that `new Worker().addModule(virtualModuleInstance)` should throw an error because its `importHook` isn‚Äôt serializable, rather than just silently stripping it off.
I‚Äôm conceding that new Worker().addModule(virtualModuleInstance) should throw an error because its importHook isn‚Äôt serializable, rather than just silently stripping it off.

content.body: Dan, Shu, and I are still arguing about how import maps get coordinated between workers, but our motives appear to be similar. Shu and I agree that the serialization of a module instance should not close over the import hook. Dan and I agree that relying on an HTTP header to indicate the import map is not sufficient either. So, something will have to give.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Dan, Shu, and I are still arguing about how import maps get coordinated between workers, but our motives appear to be similar. Shu and I agree that the serialization of a module instance should not close over the import hook. Dan and I agree that relying on an HTTP header to indicate the import map is not sufficient either. So, something will have to give.

content.body: It seems like everyone would be satisfied if in the fullness of time, workers can either inherit the host environment‚Äôs import-map or be expressly constructed with an import-map, or both.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: It seems like everyone would be satisfied if in the fullness of time, workers can either inherit the host environment‚Äôs import-map or be expressly constructed with an import-map, or both.

content.body: Guy very briefly alluded to the possibility and constraints on runtime evolution of an import-map, which I think is sufficiently tricky that I‚Äôd like to not think about it. But, in short, import-maps could evolve at runtime as long as appending a new scope does not contradict any resolution already achieved. That problem is considerably simpler if it‚Äôs not possible to resolve references that are outside of a known scope.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Guy very briefly alluded to the possibility and constraints on runtime evolution of an import-map, which I think is sufficiently tricky that I‚Äôd like to not think about it. But, in short, import-maps could evolve at runtime as long as appending a new scope does not contradict any resolution already achieved. That problem is considerably simpler if it‚Äôs not possible to resolve references that are outside of a known scope.

content.body: Otherwise, whether a new scope can be added depends on whether a module in that scope was already loaded. Yikes.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Otherwise, whether a new scope can be added depends on whether a module in that scope was already loaded. Yikes.

content.body: Similar weird things around appending a scope that has a common prefix with an existing scope.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Similar weird things around appending a scope that has a common prefix with an existing scope.

content.body:
Great summary, thanks Kris for the clarity. With regards to import map extension, there was some fruitful discussion in https://github.com/guybedford/import-maps-extensions/issues/17.

For most use cases though, I think web sandboxes just are fine with using iframes. So the 99% use case remains static maps as opposed to dynamic. I can get behind serialization or not, ideally only as an alternative if there aren't other means of achieving the use case.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text:
Great summary, thanks Kris for the clarity. With regards to import map extension, there was some fruitful discussion in https://github.com/guybedford/import-maps-extensions/issues/17.

For most use cases though, I think web sandboxes just are fine with using iframes. So the 99% use case remains static maps as opposed to dynamic. I can get behind serialization or not, ideally only as an alternative if there aren't other means of achieving the use case.
